columns.text: In this problem, we will use the company's weighted average cost of capital in order to find their optimal debt-equity ratio.

We can also see that in the given, the cost of debt is given as pre-tax. This means that we still need to solve for the after-tax cost of debt. This can be simply done by multiplying the pre-tax value by one minus the tax rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax cost of debt}&=0.058 \times (1-0.25)\\[15 pt]
&=0.0435
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax cost of debt is $0.0435$ or $4.35\%$

Now that we already assigned values to the unknown and got the after-tax cost of debt, we can start solving using the formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
0.079&=(0.0435 \times \text{w})+[0.11 \times (1-\text{w})]\\[15 pt]
0.079&=0.0435\text{w}+0.11 -0.11\text{w}\\[15 pt]
0.0665\text{w}&=0.031\\[15 pt]
\text{w}&=\dfrac{0.031}{0.0665}\\[15 pt]
&=0.4662
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the weight of debt is $0.4662$ or $46.62\%$

We can then solve for the weight of equity by subtracting the weight of debt from 1.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weight of equity}&=1.00-0.4662\\[15 pt]
&=0.5338
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the weight of equity is $0.5338$ or $53.38\%$

We can now solve for the debt-equity ratio by taking the weight of debt and dividing it by the weight of equity.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Debt-Equity ratio}&=\dfrac{0.4662}{0.5338}\\[15 pt]
&=0.8734
\end{aligned}$$

The debt-equity ratio is $0.8734$ which means that $87.24\%$ of the company's value is from debt.
